comment.author: 54017078@N00
comment._content: They look Swedish, or maybe Norwegian.

comment.author: 51035785936@N01
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54017078@N00] I was thinking the same thing. The headdress on the woman in the middle makes me think she's from Hardanger or another western region in Norway.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Great start to the conversation.... Based on my (small) knowledge of Norwegain traditional dress, I'm pretty sure it's not Hardanger - the brooches don't look like the traditional Norwegian solje - they usually have dangling silver discs - and the Hardanger bodice has an embroidered insert. I tend to agree with Swedish. Anyone got any more suggestions? EG
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51035785936@N01
comment._content: I'm wondering if they perhaps made these themselves, after arrival to Australia. Wearing the traditional thick wool garments in the Australian climate would probably lead to heat strokes... Before the 1950's, people weren't as strict with the precise details either. Our Norwegian national holiday is in just a couple days, so these outfits will be filling the streets soon!

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brusse] It's highly possible that they made them themselves. I had a Hardanger costume as a child, so I'm still pretty confident that this isn't Hardanger. Could be from somewhere else in Norway though! Happy Syttende Mai for Friday! EG
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 54017078@N00
comment._content: OK, I'm pretty sure it's Sweden! There is such a big variation between the different parts of the country, but this dress from Rättvik (province of Dalarna) looks so much like the outfit on the right, looking at the bodice especially: www.hosinger.se/2010/06/02/min-folkdrakt-rattviksdrakten/ And the middle dress here (possibly from Dalsland): media1.vgregion.se/vastarvet/DFH/samlingarna/Bilder/HA081... looks a lot like the outfit on the left above.

comment.author: 51035785936@N01
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] y family lived in Chicago for many years before moving back to Norway. I remember many decendants of Norwegian immigrants would mix and match various parts of bunads they had inherited, much to the dismay of those newly arriving from Norway. Wish I had a bunad, but they're so expencive, I'd rather use the money to visit Australia again...

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Looks pretty good for Swedish. Want to have a crack at the next two photos in the photostream? www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/8734484362/in/pho... and www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/8733364571/in/pho...
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brusse] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brusse] They are VERY expensive, aren;t they! No wonder most people make their own. Mine was borrowed, which was why it was Hardanger - my grandfather was actually from Aust-Agder. EG
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection
